questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents for a routine gynecological examination. She has no complaints and her Pap smear two years ago was normal. Which types of human papillomavirus (HPV) is she most likely to be vaccinated against to reduce her risk of developing cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HPV types 16 & 18

 

Option A:

 

HPV types 16 and 18 are high-risk strains that are strongly associated with the development of cervical cancer. Vaccines targeting these types are given to reduce the risk of cervical cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. HPV types 6 & 11 are associated with the development of genital warts and are low-risk types for cervical cancer.

 

Option C. HPV types 31 & 32 are also high-risk strains but less commonly associated with cervical cancer compared to types 16 & 18.

 

Option D. HPV types 1 & 2 are not associated with cervical cancer; they typically cause common skin warts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)–  Type 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Cervical cancer – 16,18,31, 33, 45 (high risk type)
  • Sq cell carcinoma and dysplasia of penis, anus, vagina and vulva; epidermodysplasia verruciformis (type 5, 8).

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e, p465

questions.text: A pediatric patient presents with a history of recurrent respiratory infections and a persistent, progressive hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy, multiple small, wart-like lesions are seen on the vocal cords. Which HPV types are most commonly responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HPV types 6 & 11

 

Option A:

 

HPV types 6 and 11 are most commonly associated with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis, which presents with laryngeal papillomas and can cause hoarseness and respiratory issues.

 

Some important Pointers –

 

  • HPV has selective tropism for epithelium of skin and mucous membranes and produces an array of infections.
  • Products of early genes E6 and E7 have oncogenic potential by following ways:
    •  E6 protein facilitates the degradation of the p53 tumor-suppressor protein
    •  E7 protein binds to the retinoblastoma gene product and related proteins.
  • CIN (Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia) is a benign condition, associated with low-risk HPV types 6 and 11
  •  Carcinoma cervix (squamous cell) is associated with high-risk HPV types such as 16 and 18 (most common); followed by 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 51–53, 56, 58, 59, 66, 68, 73 and 82.
  •  High-risk serotypes are associated with squamous cell carcinoma involving other genital regions such as penis, anus, vagina, and vulva.
  •  Head and neck lesions
    •  Benign: Recurrent laryngeal papillomas in children are associated with low-risk serotypes 6 and 11.
    •  Malignant: Laryngeal and esophageal carcinomas (associated with high-risk serotypes 16 and 18).

Explanation:

 

Option B. HPV types 16 & 18 are high-risk types associated with anogenital cancers and are less likely to cause laryngeal papillomatosis.

 

Option C. HPV types 33 & 45 are also considered high-risk for cancer but not commonly associated with laryngeal papillomas.

 

Option D. HPV types 4 & 27 are typically responsible for common skin warts, not laryngeal papillomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV types 6 and 11 are commonly associated with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis, presenting as laryngeal papillomas. This condition is characterized by hoarseness and respiratory infections in pediatric patients, identifiable through laryngoscopic examination.

 

  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)– Type 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Cervical cancer – 16,18,31, 33, 45 (high risk type)
  • Sq cell carcinoma and dysplasia of penis, anus, vagina and vulva; epidermodysplasia verruciformis (type 5, 8).

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p466, Harrison 19/e p 1199; Medical microbiology p 786

choices.text: HPV is an RNA virus.
The most recent vaccine developed against HPV is a 7-valent vaccine.
HPV type 16 is most commonly associated with cervical cancer.

questions.text: In a lecture about human papillomavirus (HPV), the professor discusses various characteristics of the virus. Which of the following statements about HPV is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HPV type 16 is most commonly associated with cervical cancer.

 

Option C:

 

HPV type 16, along with type 18, is the high-risk strain most commonly associated with cervical cancer. The statement is true and reflects the importance of HPV vaccination in preventing high-risk HPV-related cancers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  HPV is a DNA virus.

 

Option B. The most recent HPV vaccine is a 9-valent vaccine, not a 7-valent vaccine.

 

Option D. HPV viruses have icosahedral symmetry, not helical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV type 16 is indeed the most commonly associated type with cervical cancer. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1e/p448, 2/e p465-466

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

questions.text: A medical student is preparing a presentation on the oncogenic potential of human papillomavirus (HPV) and is discussing the various cancers associated with the virus. Which of the following cancers is HPV not commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Testicular cancer

 

Option D:

 

HPV is not commonly associated with testicular cancer. Instead, HPV is known to be associated with various mucosal squamous cell carcinomas, including cervical and oropharyngeal cancers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While bladder cancer is not commonly caused by HPV, HPV DNA can sometimes be found in bladder carcinomas, but the association is not strong.

 

Option B. HPV, especially types 16 and 18, is well-known to be associated with oropharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Option C. HPV can be associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, especially in immunosuppressed individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV is predominantly associated with various mucosal squamous cell carcinomas, especially in areas like the cervix and oropharynx.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p448, 2/e p465-466, Harrison 19th/p1198, 20/e p1371

choices.text: Carcinoma at the base of the tongue

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the otolaryngology clinic with a lesion at the base of the tongue. He has a history of heavy smoking and alcohol use. A biopsy is performed, and the pathology report suggests a squamous cell carcinoma. The patient asks about the role of HPV in head and neck cancers. Which of the following cancers is least likely to be associated with HPV?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

Option C:

 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is more commonly associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) rather than HPV. HPV is a known risk factor for oropharyngeal cancers, particularly those at the base of the tongue and the tonsils, but not for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Carcinoma at the base of the tongue is often associated with high-risk HPV types, particularly type 16.

 

Option B. Tonsillar carcinoma is also associated with HPV, especially in non-smokers.

 

Option D. Recurrent respiratory papilloma is caused by low-risk HPV types 6 and 11, and while benign, it can undergo malignant transformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is predominantly associated with the Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV), not HPV. While HPV is a significant risk factor for various oropharyngeal cancers, particularly those occurring at the base of the tongue and in the tonsils, it is not commonly linked to nasopharyngeal carcinoma. HPV's oncogenic potential primarily affects squamous cells in the oropharyngeal region, rather than in the nasopharynx.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p448, 2/e p465-466

choices.text: The vaccine protects against only one HPV strain.
The vaccine includes strains 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 52, and 58.
Three doses are recommended for girls if the vaccination series is started after the age of 15.
Two doses with a 6-month interval are recommended for girls aged 9–14 years.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother for a health maintenance visit. Her mother inquires about vaccinations recommended for her daughter. According to the current WHO recommendations, which of the following statements about the HPV vaccination is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Two doses with a 6-month interval are recommended for girls aged 9–14 years.

 

Option D:

 

The current WHO recommendations for HPV vaccination suggest that two doses with a 6-month interval are recommended for girls aged 9–14 years. This is because the immune response in young adolescents is more robust, allowing for a two-dose schedule.

 

HPV Genome

 

  • Circular double stranded DNA genome containing 800 base pairs.
    • Encodes 6 Early genes (E1, E2, E4, E5, E6, E7) and 2 Late genes (L1, L2)
    • Early genes regulate DNA viral replication, Late genes encode Viral capsid.
  • HPV vaccines target L1, L2 genes: Capsid proteins of L1, L2 act as Target antigens
    • L1 is targeted more by Cervarix, Gardasil 
    • L2 based vaccines are cheaper but less immunogenic.

 

Currently two Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) vaccines are available in India as a protection against cervical cancer.

 

  • Gardasil vaccine: HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18 (Quadrivalent)
  • Cervarix vaccine: HPV types 16, 18 (Bivalent)

 

Nine valent vaccine (Gardasil 9, Merck): 

 

Includes seven common cancer-causing serotypes (16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58) and two noncancer causing serotypes (6 and 11)

 

It is given IM; either as 2 doses (6 months’ gap) between 9–14 yrs or 3 doses (0, 2 and 6 months) between 14–26 yrs age

 

Immune response is better if given earlier (<14 yrs)

 

Protection appears to be long lasting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HPV vaccine is not monovalent; it protects against multiple strains.

 

Option B. Vaccine does protect against multiple strains, the option listed includes both current and past vaccine types in a format not represented by any one vaccine.

 

Option C. Three doses are recommended if the vaccination series is started at or after the age of 15.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SAGE recommends updating dose schedules for HPV – 

 

  • One or two-dose schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14
  • One or two-dose schedule for young women aged 15-20 
  • Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e, p466

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents with a cluster of small, flesh-colored, cauliflower-like lesions in the genital area. 

 

 

He is in a monogamous relationship and denies any history of similar lesions in the past. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human papillomavirus (HPV)

 

Option B:
 

Genital warts, known as condyloma acuminata, are most commonly caused by low-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11. They are characterized by their distinctive cauliflower-like appearance.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex virus typically causes painful vesicular lesions rather than cauliflower-like warts.

 

Option C. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) does not commonly cause genital lesions.

 

Option D. Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) causes chickenpox and shingles, not genital warts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV as the most common viral sexually transmitted infection causing genital warts, with types 6 and 11 being most frequently implicated.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med.Microbiology, 2/e p465

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of progressive weakness and cognitive decline is evaluated for demyelinating disease. MRI of the brain shows multifocal white matter lesions. A diagnosis of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is considered. Which virus is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) JC virus

 

Option C:

 

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is most commonly caused by the JC virus, a human polyomavirus. It typically occurs in individuals with a compromised immune system.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CMV can cause CMV encephalitis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, but not typically PML.

 

Option B. EBV is associated with a variety of conditions including infectious mononucleosis and is linked to certain types of cancer, but not PML.

 

Option D. RSV is a common cause of respiratory infections, particularly in children, and is not associated with PML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The JC virus is the etiological agent of PML, a rare and often fatal demyelinating disease that occurs in immunocompromised patients

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p448-49, 2/e p465-466, Harrison 20/e p1371

questions.text: During an STI clinic visit, a patient present with multiple, soft, flesh-colored, verrucous lesions around the genital area. What is the causative agent of this condition, known as condyloma acuminatum?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human Papillomavirus (HPV)

 

Option B:

 

Condyloma acuminatum, characterized by soft, verrucous (wart-like), flesh-colored lesions in the genital area, is most commonly caused by certain strains of Human Papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV types 6 and 11. These types of HPV are highly contagious and are typically transmitted through sexual contact. The lesions are a distinct manifestation of HPV infection in the genital region.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HSV causes herpes genitalis, which is characterized by painful vesicles and ulcers, not warts.

 

Option C. HIV is the virus that causes AIDS and is not directly responsible for the development of condyloma acuminatum.

 

Option D. VZV causes chickenpox and shingles, not genital warts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminatum, also known as genital warts, is most commonly caused by HPV, particularly types 6 and 11.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p448-49, 2/e p465-466, Harrison 20/e p1371

questions.text: A public health researcher is analyzing data for a study on the prevalence of cervical cancer and its associated risk factors. She notes that certain HPV serotypes have a higher prevalence in cervical cancer biopsies. Which HPV serotype is most commonly associated with cervical cancer (CaCx)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HPV-16

 

Option C:

 

HPV-16 is the serotype most commonly associated with cervical cancer. High-risk HPV types, particularly HPV-16 (and also HPV-18), are known to be key etiological agents in the development of cervical cancer. These serotypes are linked to the majority of cervical cancer cases due to their oncogenic potential, which can lead to the transformation of cervical epithelial cells into cancerous cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HPV-6 is commonly associated with benign genital warts and has a low oncogenic potential.

 

Option B. HPV-11 is also associated with benign genital warts and has a low risk of causing cervical cancer.

 

Option D. HPV-33 is a high-risk HPV type but is less common than HPV-16 in cervical cancer cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV-16 is the most common serotype found in cervical cancer biopsies and is known for its high oncogenic potential.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p448-49, 2/e p465-466

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought in by her parents for HPV vaccination. The parents have questions about the composition of the quadrivalent vaccine. Which of the following HPV types is not included in the quadrivalent vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 7

 

Option A:

 

The quadrivalent HPV vaccine includes types 6, 11, 16, and 18. Type 7 is not included in the vaccine and is not an HPV type associated with genital warts or cervical cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Type 11 is included in the quadrivalent vaccine and is associated with genital warts.

 

Option C. Type 16 is included and is a high-risk type associated with cervical and other anogenital cancers.

 

Option D. Type 18 is also included in the quadrivalent vaccine and is another high-risk type associated with cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV types included in the quadrivalent vaccine, are types 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p448-49, 2/e p465-466, Harrison 19/e p1199, 20/e p1371, 18/e p1483-84
